scenario:
The Vanguard Dividend Appreciation ETF (VIG) offers a low-cost investment option that balances growth and income. The fund has over 330 holdings, a 0.06% expense ratio, and a price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio of 25. It has a dividend yield of 1.7% compared to the Vanguard S&P 500 ETF's 1.2% yield. The fund prioritizes companies with high earnings and dividend growth, including top-tier growth stocks like Apple, Microsoft, and Broadcom, as well as JPMorgan Chase and UnitedHealth Group.

The fund is heavily invested in five sectors: technology (23%), financials (21%), healthcare (14%), industrials (13%), and consumer staples (12%). Many of these companies have a history of raising their dividends, with some having done so for over a decade. The fund's valuation is relatively inexpensive, with a P/E ratio lower than the S&P 500.

Key holdings include:

- Apple (13 years of consecutive dividend raises)
- Microsoft (15 years of consecutive dividend raises)
- Broadcom (over 80% increase in dividend in the last five years)
- JPMorgan Chase (10 years of consecutive dividend raises)
- UnitedHealth Group (part of the healthcare sector with a history of dividend growth)

The Vanguard Dividend Appreciation ETF is a good fit for investors looking for a balanced portfolio of quality businesses with a runway for earnings and dividend growth. It is a low-cost, passive investment option that can be used to put new capital to work in the stock market.
